{{More citations needed|date=October 2009}}
{{Infobox organization | logo = Global Health Counci.png | type = Advocacy | key_people = Loyce Pace, President & Executive Director (December 2016- )<ref name="Leadership">{{cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/about-us/board-of-directors-2/ |title=Global Health Council Leadership |publisher=Globalhealth.org |accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref> | footnotes = | name = Global Health Council | founded_date = 1972<ref name="Who We Are"/> | founder = | location = [[Washington, DC]] <ref name="Who We Are"/><!-- this parameter modifies "Headquarters" --> | origins = | area_served = Worldwide | product = | focus = Global Health, Access and Information | method = Networking, Organizational Membership | revenue = $808,340 (2015) <ref name="2015 Form 990">{{cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/GHC-990-PD-2015.pdf |title=2015 Form 990 Global Health Council, Inc. |publisher=Globalhealth.org |accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | Non-profit_slogan = "The Collective Voice of the Global Health Community" | homepage = [http://www.globalhealth.org/ www.GlobalHealth.org] }} The '''Global Health Council''' is a United States-based non-profit leading networking organization "supporting and connecting advocates, implementers and stakeholders around global health priorities worldwide".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/about-us/mission-and-vision/|title=Global Health Council {{!}} About Us|website=globalhealth.org|access-date=2016-11-29}}</ref> The Council is the world's largest membership alliance dedicated to advancing policies and programs that improve health around the world.<ref>{{cite book | last = Foege | first =William H. | authorlink = William Foege |author2=Nils Daulaire |author3=Robert E. Black |author4=Clarence E. Pearson | title=Global Health Leadership and Management: partners in global health and development | publisher = Jossey-Bass | location = San Francisco | isbn= 9780787971533 | year=2005 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=TISPFr48k5YC | accessdate=2008-10-22}}</ref> The Council serves and represents thousands of public health professionals from over 150 countries across the globe.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/22/AR2007082202847.html |title=Foreign Aid Groups Face Terror Screens — washingtonpost.com |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date= 2007-08-23|accessdate=2008-10-26 | first=Walter | last=Pincus}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/about-us/member-directory/|title=Global Health Council — Member Directory|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Globalhealth.org|accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref> They work "to improve health globally through increased investment, robust policies and the power of the collective voice.":<ref name="Who We Are"/> According to their website the Council "convenes stakeholders around key global health priorities and actively engages key decision makers to influence health policy."<ref name="Who We Are">{{cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/about-us/mission-and-vision/|title=Global Health Council — About Us|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Globalhealth.org|accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref>
After shutting its doors in 2012,<ref>http://www.globalhealth.org/Home_Page.html</ref> GHC re-opened with a newly elected board of directors on January 1, 2013.<ref>http://www.humanosphere.org/2013/02/the-sudden-death-and-rebirth-of-the-global-health-council/</ref> In their new model, the Global Health Council works in three main areas: policy and advocacy, member engagement, and connections and coordination.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/what-we-do/|title=Global Health Council {{!}} What We Do|website=globalhealth.org|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> Reflecting this focus, GHC offers an online platform that includes guest blogs, member spotlights, policy briefs, advocacy updates, and global health job postings. Additionally, the GHC has since participated in significant global health events at the national and international level including the World Health Assembly, Global Health Week on the Hill, and the Consortium of Universities for Global Health Consortium.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digimag.internationalinnovation.com//launch.aspx?eid=1cee8b62-2d6f-44de-8df5-23dacb356978&pnum=28|title=International Innovation - Issue 127 digital edition|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref>
The Council coordinates and participates in a number of working groups, coalitions, and roundtables in the global health advocacy community, including the GHC Budget Roundtable and Global Health Security Roundtable.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/what-we-do/policy-advocacy/advocacy-community/|title=Global Health Council {{!}} Global Health Advocacy Community|website=globalhealth.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> The Council maintains a global health Advocacy Hub<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/what-we-do/policy-advocacy/advocacy-hub/|title=Global Health Council {{!}} Advocacy Hub|website=globalhealth.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> and coordinates the biennial publication of the Global Health Briefing Book. The most recent publication, titled ''Global Health Works: Maximizing U.S. Investments for Healthier and Stronger Communities,'' was released in 2017 for the 115th U.S. Congress.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://publichealth.gwu.edu/blogs/careers/2017/02/15/global-health-council-launches-global-health-briefing-book/|title=Global Health Council Launches Global Health Briefing Book {{!}} Career Services|website=publichealth.gwu.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref>
==History==
Through almost five decades of work, the Global Health Council has continuously served as the leading membership organization focused on global health advocacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/global-health-council-taps-loyce-133000140.html|title=Global Health Council Taps Loyce Pace As New Executive Director – PR Newswire on Yahoo Finance|last=|first=|date=2016-10-20|website=www.csrwire.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
In 1972, the ‘National Council for International Health’ was first established. In 1998, the organization became the Global Health Council to better represent its work in the 21st century. As the council evolved, its name had to evolve to correctly reflect the scope of the Council's work. The inclusion of global in its name reflected the Council's goal to include more international organizations and individuals in its membership and become the preeminent non-governmental source of information, practical experience, analysis and public advocacy for the most pressing global health issues.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/Pdaby237.pdf|title=EVALUATION OF THE GLOBAL HEALTH COUNCIL|last=Pielemeier|first=John|date=November 2002|website=USAID.gov|access-date=}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}}
In 1998, the Council began organizing the Global Health Action Network in pursuit of its advocacy building goals.<ref name="GHAC">[http://www.globalhealth.org/view_top.php3?id=16 Global Health Action Network]</ref> The network was designed to establish groups of motivated citizens across the U.S. to educate local communities and their elected officials about the need for a more proactive approach to global health. With this network in place, the Council was able to implement nationwide advocacy campaigns dealing with vital global health issues. The Council continued to grow as the voice for global health by using its annual conference; its website to promote advocacy, education and information sharing; its media outreach through a diverse field of multi-disciplinary specialists;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE0D91239F932A15755C0A9629C8B63&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=2|title=U.S. Is Accused of Trying to Isolate U.N. Population Unit — New York Times|date=June 21, 2004|publisher=Query.nytimes.com|author=Christopher Marquis|accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/activity/2007/sep/25/|title=Today in Congress: September 25, 2007 | washingtonpost.com|publisher=Projects.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=2008-10-26}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/26/AR2007052600124.html|title=The Week Ahead: May 28-June 1 — washingtonpost.com|date=2007-05-27|publisher=Washingtonpost.com|accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref> and its publications, including the Global Health Magazine ".<ref name="GHM">[http://www.globalhealthmagazine.com The Global Health Magazine]</ref>
As part of the Council's work in advocacy and developing awareness of the [[AIDS]] crisis, the seventeen-year-old International AIDS Candlelight Memorial event came under their stewardship in 1999.<ref>[http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PDABY237.pdf Evaluation of the Global Health Council]</ref> The International AIDS Candlelight Memorial grew to include 1,500 communities in more than 100 countries.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080807130454/http://www.candlelightmemorial.org/images/pdf/al_special.pdf 25 Years of AIDS Candlelight Memorial Parallels History of AIDS Epidemic] "Global AIDSLink" www.globalhealth.org | November/December 2007 | #106.</ref> It is the world's largest and oldest [[grassroots]] HIV/AIDS event.<ref>[http://www.nbcsvg.com/news/article.php?index=3705 AIDS Candlelight Memorial] NBC Radio, 2008-12-23. {{Dead link|date=December 2010}}</ref>
In April 2012, the Global Health Council announced it would be closing its doors for the upcoming months. The Board of Directors released the announcement acknowledging that, “although the Global Health Council will no longer play the same role, we will continue to fight for the goals that first inspired us to action.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kff.org/news-summary/global-health-council-to-close-operations-this-year/|title=Global Health Council To Close Operations This Year|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref>
With no unified voice for global health in the advocacy sphere, 40 international organizations came together at the end of 2012 to pledge almost $300,000 over three years to establish a new Global Health Council. The new Council included a newly elected Board of Directors and leaner business model.<ref name="internationalinnovation.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.internationalinnovation.com/a-shared-voice-for-global-health/|title=Global Health Council - International Innovation|date=2014-07-02|newspaper=International Innovation|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> In January 2013, the Global Health Council reopened its doors to continue their mission bringing global health concerns to the forefront of policy work. The Council added Global Impact to serve as the organization Secretariat, in order to allow the Council to focus on advocacy through convening, communications, and coalition-building.<ref name="internationalinnovation.com"/> Dr. Christine Sow was selected as its new Executive Director, becoming the first woman to lead the organization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csrwire.com/press_releases/36322-Global-Health-Council-Taps-a-Passionate-Voice-for-the-Voiceless-as-Its-New-Executive-Director|title=Global Health Council Taps a "Passionate Voice for the Voiceless" as Its New Executive Director – Press Releases on CSRwire.com|website=www.csrwire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref>
GHC has hundreds of individual and organizational members representing a number of sectors in the global health field. In 2014, GHC member organizations operated in more than 150 countries worldwide and had a combined annual revenue of over $40 billion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/about-us/member-directory/|title=Global Health Council {{!}} Members|website=globalhealth.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> The Board of Directors is led by Dr. Jonathan Quick of Management Sciences for Health (MSH).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://globalhealth.org/about-us/board-of-directors-2/|title=Global Health Council {{!}} Leadership|website=globalhealth.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> Loyce Pace became President and Executive Director of the organization in December 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msh.org/news-events/press-room/management-sciences-for-health-welcomes-appointment-of-loyce-pace-as-global|title=MANAGEMENT SCIENCES FOR HEALTH WELCOMES APPOINTMENT OF LOYCE PACE AS GLOBAL HEALTH COUNCIL’S NEW EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Focus== * [[Women's health]] * [[:Category:Pediatrics|Child health]] * [[HIV/AIDS]] * [[Infectious diseases]] * [[Health Threat Unit (European Commission)|Emerging health threats]]
==Awards== The Council has administered a number of prominent awards. Some of the recipients have been barred from traveling to receive them which has brought attention to their work.<ref name="ACIAW"/> In addition to the following honorific awards the organization has also conferred the "Best Practices in Global Health Award" and the "Excellence in Media Award for Global Health".
===Jonathan Mann Award for Health and Human Rights=== The Jonathan Mann Award for Health and Human Rights is named for former head of the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO)'s global [[AIDS]] program, [[Jonathan Mann (WHO official)|Jonathan Mann]], who resigned to protest the lack of response from the [[United Nations]] and WHO with regard to AIDS.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/aids/ "The age of AIDS"] [[PBS Frontline]] documentary.</ref> In 2001, the recipient was [[Gao Yaojie]], a retired Chinese gynecologist and one of China's foremost AIDS fighters who helped poor farmers in Henan Province that were infected with H.I.V. through selling their blood at for-profit and unsanitary collection stations.<ref name="ACIAW">[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9C0CE7DB113CF932A05756C0A9679C8B63 '' AIDS Crusader's International Award Wins Scowls in China''] by Elisabeth Rosenthal, New York Times, 31 May 2001.</ref> Yaojie was denied permission to attend an awards ceremony in Washington with Secretary General [[Kofi Annan]] of the United Nations as her host.<ref name="ACIAW"/>
In 2008, the Mann award was to be given to [[Binayak Sen]], a prominent Indian doctor responsible for drawing up one of the most successful community-based health-care models in India — based on the traditional [[mitanin]], a health worker who advises the rural poor on preventive care — making health care available to many who had lacked access.<ref name="NLUTWR">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/29/AR2008052903578.html ''Nobel Laureates Unable to Win Release of Doctor''] by Nora Boustany, Washington Post, 30 May 2008.</ref> He had been a vocal critic of the government's use of armed groups to push villagers out of mineral-rich forests to boost development and was jailed in April 2007 on sedition charges, including allegedly being linked to Maoist rebels and smuggling a letter for an accused Maoist prisoner he had visited.<ref name="NLUTWR"/> Sen denies the charges and his effort to get the award in person was bolstered by 22 [[Nobel laureate]]s; he is out of jail on bail.
===Gates Award=== Named for and funded by [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]], the Microsoft Corp. founder and his wife, the Gates Award ($1 million) is administered by the Council.<ref name="gagtb"/> In 2004 the award went to Fazle Hasan Abed and his organization, [[Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee]] (BRAC), one of the "world's most successful development organizations, credited with improving the health and welfare of tens of millions of destitute people in Bangladesh".<ref name="gagtb"/> Past winners include the Rotary Foundation, which has raised millions for an ongoing global campaign to stamp out [[polio]].<ref name="gagtb">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A11257-2004Jun2.html ''Gates Award Goes to Bangladeshi Aid Group: Rural Organization BRAC Is Credited With Improving the Lives of Millions''] by Justin Gillis, Washington Post — 3 June 2004.</ref>
The winner of the 2009 Gates Award was awarded to The [[London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine]].<ref name="2009Gates">[http://www.gatesfoundation.org/press-releases/Pages/london-school-wins-global-health-gates-award.aspx "London School Wins Global Health Gates Award"] 18 May 2009.</ref>
==Funding== From its inception through the 1990s, the Council was principally funded by grants (primarily from the [[U.S. Agency for International Development]] [USAID] and the [[Centers for Disease Control]] [CDC])."<ref name="ABA HRM">[http://www.abanet.org/irr/hr/winter08/herowinter08.html Human Rights magazine]</ref> In 1998, [[Nils Daulaire]], formerly of USAID, became president of The Global Health Council and felt that the council should be an independent voice.<ref name="ABA HRM"/> The council diversified its funding as a matter of principle, even though at the time its policy agenda was consistent with that of the then administration.<ref name="ABA HRM"/> By 2003, only 20 percent of the council’s funding came from the U.S. government."<ref name="ABA HRM"/>
The Council has received grants of varying sizes from a variety of foundations, including the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation|Gates]], [[David and Lucile Packard Foundation|Packard]], [[Hewlett Foundation|Hewlett MacArthur]], and [[Rockefeller Foundation|Rockefeller]].<ref name=":0" />
As part of the [[President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief]], US government support for AIDS prevention was contingent on [[Anti-prostitution pledge|opposing prostitution]] starting in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|author = [[Adam Liptak|Liptak, Adam]] |title = Justices Say U.S. Cannot Impose Antiprostitution Condition on AIDS Grants|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/21/us/court-finds-aids-programs-rules-violate-free-speech.html|accessdate = 25 June 2013|newspaper = [[The New York Times]]|date = 20 June 2013}}</ref> The Council preferred to remain neutral so as not to alienate sex workers from their ant-HIV efforts so they sued in federal court with other non-profits.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mientka, Matthew |title=US Supreme Court Divides On Free Speech Rights Of Health Groups |url=http://www.medicaldaily.com/articles/14799/20130422/supreme-court-divides-free-speech-rights-health.htm| work=Medical Daily |publisher=[[International Business Times|IBT Media]]|date=22 April 2013|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref> In 2013, the U.S. Supreme Court found that the requirement violated the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment's]] prohibition against compelled speech in ''[[Agency for International Development v. Alliance for Open Society International, Inc.]]''<ref>{{cite web|author=[[John Roberts|Roberts, John]]|title=AGENCY FOR INT’L DEVELOPMENT v. ALLIANCE FOR |url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/12-10#writing-12-10_OPINION_3|work=[[Legal Information Institute]]|publisher=[[Cornell Law School]]|date=20 June 2013|accessdate=17 July 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110119175716/https://www.globalhealth.org/view_top.php3?id=39 Board of Directors] * [http://www.globalhealth.org/view_top.php3?id=232 Member Organizations]

revision.comment: Restating of the current use of GMDN by the European Commission and Member States under existing regulation. References were cited to existing regulations and future proposed regulations on medical device safety.-
revision.text:
'''Global Medical Device Nomenclature''' ('''GMDN''') is a system of internationally agreed generic descriptors used to identify all [[medical device]] products. This [[nomenclature]] is a naming system for products which include those used for the diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, treatment or alleviation of disease or injury in humans.
The main purpose of the GMDN is to provide health authorities / regulators, health care providers, [[conformity assessment]] bodies and others with a single generic naming system.
Medical device experts from around the world (manufacturers, healthcare authorities and regulators) compiled the GMDN, based on the international standard [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] 15225.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=50728|title=ISO 15225:2010 - Medical devices -- Quality management -- Medical device nomenclature data structure|website=www.iso.org}}</ref> The work was mandated by the European Commission in order to provide the necessary tool to carry out the implementation of the [[Medical Devices Directive]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/medical-devices/regulatory-framework/index_en.htm|title=Public Health - European Commission|website=Public Health}}</ref> including the European databank for medical devices (Eudamed).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/medical-devices/market-surveillance-vigilance/index_en.htm|title=Public Health - European Commission|website=Public Health}}</ref>
In the draft of the proposed Medical Device Regulation (from the European Commission) it states “To facilitate the functioning of the European Databank on medical devices (Eudamed), a medical device nomenclature should be available free of charge to manufacturers and other natural or legal persons obliged to use that nomenclature under this Regulation. Furthermore this nomenclature should be provided, to the maximum possible extent free of charge, also to other stakeholders.”
The GMDN is the current nomenclature used by Members States in the National Competent Authority Reports as part of the current EUDAMED system to exchange information on device safety<ref>https://ec.europa.eu/growth/sectors/medical-devices/market-surveillance_en</ref>. The GMDN is not yet specified for the UDI database system proposed in new European Regulations<ref>https://ec.europa.eu/growth/sectors/medical-devices/regulatory-framework_en#new_regulations</ref> intended to be used by manufacturers of medical devices who have their own UDIs (unique device identifiers) and traceability.
==Governance== The GMDN meets the need to identify medical devices at the global level, as identified in the [[Global Harmonization Task Force]] (GHTF) that have since disbanded (2012) and replaced by the IMDRF<ref>http://www.imdrf.org/about/about.asp</ref>
GMDN is managed by the GMDN Agency, a [[non-profit organization]] and Registered Charity,<ref>[[Charitable organization#United Kingdom]]</ref> which reports to its Board of Trustees, that represent medical device regulators and industry.
==Structure== The GMDN term is in the form of a 5-digit numeric GMDN Code cross-referenced to a specific Term Name and Definition, with which all specific medical devices having substantially similar generic features, can be identified. The following is an example:
* GMDN Term Name - "Scalpel, single-use" * GMDN Code - "47569" * GMDN Definition - "A sterile, hand-held, manual surgical instrument constructed as a one-piece handle and scalpel blade (not an exchangeable component) used by the operator to manually cut or dissect tissue. The blade is typically made of high-grade stainless steel alloy or carbon steel and the handle is often made of plastic. This is a single-use device."
The GMDN term and other associated data is [[copyright]] protected and the GMDN is a [[Trademark]].
Uniquely each GMDN term has a set of attributes, known as Collective Terms, which help to navigate the GMDN Database and aid the selection of a GMDN term by medical condition or product feature.
The GMDN is used by regulators, healthcare providers and others for activities such as medical device recalls, adverse event reporting and postmarket surveillance and monitoring, as well as inventory control and other healthcare management functions.
The GMDN Agency updates the GMDN utilizing member change requests, to add a new generic device term or to change an existing Term Name or Definition. The decisions are made by an international expert team, according to ISO 15225. The GMDN Agency releases updates to the GMDN on a daily basis, on their interactive website, the GMDN Database.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmdnagency.org/|title=GMDN Agency|website=www.gmdnagency.org}}</ref> Only Members have access to the GMDN Database and membership is priced according to organization type and size. The GMDN is available in English and other languages.
==International use== The GMDN is used in the European Databank on Medical Devices (Eudamed)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/medical-devices/market-surveillance-vigilance/eudamed/index_en.htm|title=Public Health - European Commission|website=Public Health}}</ref> which has been established by the European Commission to strengthen [[market surveillance]] and vigilance.
The GMDN has been identified as part of the 'minimum data set' for the proposed US FDA<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/UniqueDeviceIdentification/default.htm|title=Unique Device Identification - UDI|first=Center for Devices and Radiological|last=Health|website=www.fda.gov}}</ref> [[Unique Device Identification]] regulation for the registration of new Medical Devices intended for use in the United States. This follows the international consensus<ref>http://www.imdrf.org/docs/imdrf/final/technical/imdrf-tech-131209-udi-guidance-140901.pdf</ref> established by the International Medical Device Regulatory Forum (IMDRF).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdrf.org|title=International Medical Device Regulators Forum|website=www.imdrf.org}}</ref>
The GMDN Agency has recently finalised the business principles that will form the basis of a long term cooperation with the [[IHTSDO]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ihtsdo.org/|title=SNOMED International|website=www.ihtsdo.org}}</ref> The Cooperation Agreement shall result in the use of the GMDN as the medical device component of [[SNOMED CT]]. This Agreement is consistent with the aims of both organisations to minimise duplication and to support harmonisation. The following objectives were agreed:
* A more comprehensive and harmonised clinical terminology * Greater utility and access to both terminologies * Opportunities to improve organisational efficiencies
The Agreement will benefit patients across the world and all users of [[SNOMED CT]] and the GMDN in promoting comprehensive terminology based medical records, covering the needs of regulators, the medical device industry and healthcare professionals. The arrangement will enhance the application of care to individual patients for medical device, patient risk and safety use cases.
==See also== * [[IHTSDO]] - International Health Terminology Standards Development Organisation * [[Meddra]] - Terminology for the pharmaceutical industry. * [[Medical device]]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gmdnagency.org/ GMDN Agency] - More information about GMDN
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gmdn}} [[Category:Classification systems]] [[Category:Health standards]]

{{about||tests performed on actual [[gold]]|Metallurgical assay|other uses|Gold standard (disambiguation)}}
In [[medicine]] and [[statistics]], '''gold standard test is''' usually [[medical diagnosis|diagnostic test]] or [[statistical test|benchmark]] that is the best available '''under reasonable conditions'''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Versi|first=E|title="Gold standard" is an appropriate term.|journal=BMJ|date=July 1992|pmid=1515860|pmc=1883235|volume=305|issue=6846|pages=187|doi=10.1136/bmj.305.6846.187-b}}</ref> Other times, gold standard is the most accurate test possible '''without restrictions'''.
Both meanings are different because for example, in medicine, dealing with conditions that would require an [[autopsy]] to have a perfect diagnosis, the gold standard test would be the best one that keeps the patient alive instead of the autopsy.
==In medicine==
"Gold standard" can refer to the criteria by which scientific evidence is evaluated. For example, in [[resuscitation]] research, the "gold standard" test of a medication or procedure is whether or not it leads to an increase in the number of neurologically intact survivors that walk out of the hospital.<ref name=ACLS_2003_Outcomes>''ACLS: Principles and Practice''. p. 62. Dallas: American Heart Association, 2003. {{ISBN|0-87493-341-2}}.</ref> Other types of medical research might regard a significant decrease in 30-day mortality as the gold standard.
The AMA Style Guide prefers the phrase ''Criterion Standard'' instead of "gold standard", and many medical journals now mandate this usage in their instructions for contributors. For instance, ''Archives of biological Medicine and Rehabilitation'' specifies this usage.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.editors/623354/authorinstructions | title = ARCHIVES OF PHYSICAL MEDICINE AND REHABILITATION: Guide for Authors | work = [[Elsevier]] |date=February 2007 | accessdate = 2007-09-11 }}</ref> When the criterion is a whole clinical testing procedure it is usually referred to as [[case definition|clinical case definition]].
A hypothetical ideal "gold standard" test has a [[sensitivity (tests)|sensitivity]] of 100% with respect to the presence of the disease (it identifies all individuals with a well defined disease process; it does not have any false-negative results) and a [[specificity (tests)|specificity]] of 100% (it does not falsely identify someone with a condition that does not have the condition; it does not have any false-positive results). In practice, there are sometimes no true "gold standard" tests.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=LM Troy, KB Michels, DJ Hunter, D Spiegelman|title=Self-reported birthweight and history of having been breastfed among younger women: an assessment of validity|year=1996|journal=Int J Epidemiol|publisher=IEA|url=http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/content/25/1/122.full.pdf|pmid=8666479|doi=10.1093/ije/25.1.122|volume=25|issue=1|pages=122–127}}</ref>
As new diagnostic methods become available, the "gold standard" test may change over time. For instance, for the diagnosis of [[aortic dissection]], the "gold standard" test used to be the [[aortogram]], which had a sensitivity as low as 83% and a specificity as low as 87%. Since the advancements of [[magnetic resonance imaging]], the [[magnetic resonance angiogram]] (MRA) has become the new "gold standard" test for aortic dissection, with a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 92%. Before widespread acceptance of any new test, the former test retains its status as the "gold standard".
==Test calibration==
Because tests can be incorrect (yielding a [[Type I and type II errors|false-negative or a false-positive]]), results should be interpreted in the context of the history, physical findings, and other test results in the individual being tested. It is within this context that the sensitivity and specificity of the "gold standard" test is determined.
When the gold standard is not a perfect one, its [[sensitivity and specificity]] must be [[calibrated]] against more accurate tests or against the definition of the condition.<ref name=Alloy/> This calibration is especially important when a perfect test is available only by autopsy. It is important to emphasize that a test has to meet some interobserver agreement, to avoid some bias induced by the study itself.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Complications and Validity of Pulmonary Angiography in Acute Pulmonary Embolism Circulation|year=1992|volume=85|issue=2|pages=462–468|pmid=1735144|doi=10.1161/01.CIR.85.2.462|url=http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/85/2/462.long|journal=Circulation|vauthors=Stein PD, Athanasoulis C, Alavi A, Greenspan RH, Hales CA, Saltzman HA, Vreim CE, Terrin ML, Weg JG }}</ref>
Calibration errors can lead to [[Medical error|misdiagnosis]].<ref>[http://www.rti.org/pubs/Calibration_Error.pdf The Impact of Calibration Error in Medical Decision Making]</ref>
==Ambiguity==
Sometimes "gold standard test" refers to the best performing test available. In these cases, there is no other criterion against which it can be compared and it is equivalent to a definition. When referring to this meaning, gold standard tests are normally not performed at all. This is because the gold standard test may be difficult to perform or may be impossible to perform on a living person (i.e. the test is performed as part of an [[autopsy]] or may take too long for the results of the test to be available to be clinically useful).
Other times, "gold standard" does not refer to the best performing test available, but the best available under reasonable conditions. For example, in this sense, a MRI is the gold standard for brain tumour diagnosis, though it is not as good as a biopsy. In this case the sensitivity and specificity of the gold standard are not 100% and it is said to be an "imperfect gold standard" or "alloyed gold standard".<ref name=Alloy>{{cite journal|authors=Donna Spiegelman, Sebastian Schneeweiss and Aidan McDermott|title=Measurement Error Correction for Logistic Regression Models with an "Alloyed Gold Standard"|journal=American Journal of Epidemiology|volume=145|issue=2|pages=184–196|url=http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/content/145/2/184.full.pdf|pmid=9006315|year=1997|doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.aje.a009089}}</ref>
The term [[ground truth]] refers to the underlying absolute state of information; the gold standard strives to represent the ground truth as closely as possible. While the gold standard is a best effort to obtain the truth, ground truth is typically collected by direct observations. In [[machine learning]] and [[information retrieval]], {{cnspan|text="ground truth" is the preferred term even when classifications may be imperfect; the gold standard is assumed to be the ground truth|date=February 2016}}.
==See also== *[[Evidence-based medicine]] *[[Ground truth]] *[[Statistical test]]
==References==
{{reflist|30em}}
{{Statistics|state=expanded}} {{Medical research studies}}

page.title: Health measures during the construction of the Panama Canal

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=April 2015}} {{generalize|date=April 2015}} {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} }} One of the greatest challenges facing the builders of the [[Panama Canal]] was dealing with the [[tropical disease]]s rife in the area. The health measures taken during the construction contributed greatly to the success of the canal's construction. These included general health care, the provision of an extensive health infrastructure, and a major program to eradicate disease-carrying [[mosquito]]es from the area.
== Background ==
===US control=== [[Image:gorgas.jpg|frame|William Crawford Gorgas, Chief Sanitary Officer to the Isthmian Commission]]
By the time the [[United States]] took control of the [[Panama Canal]] project on May 4, 1904, the [[Isthmus of Panama]] was notorious for [[tropical disease]]s. An estimated 12,000 workers had died during the construction of the [[Panama Railway]] and over 22,000 during the French effort to build a canal.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pancanal.com/eng/history/history/french.html | title=The French Canal Construction | accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref> Many of these deaths were due to disease, particularly [[yellow fever]] and [[malaria]]. At several times, construction on the Panama Railway had actually halted due to the lack of healthy workers.
The high rate of deaths among workers on the Panama Canal due to disease was the source of a great deal of controversy in the United States. Newspapers, such as [[The Independent (Boston)|''The Independent'']], frequently reported on the poor conditions workers in the Canal Zone experienced, including the rampant disease. [[Poultney Bigelow]] wrote an article in ''The Independent'' in 1906 critiquing the work on the Panama Canal, which was highly influential with the American public. Among other topics, Bigelow brought attention to the poor living conditions of the workers, including pools of standing water where [[mosquitoes]] could breed and spread disease from.<ref>{{cite journal | jstor=40574566 | title=Theodore Roosevelt and the Heroes of Panama | author=Hogan, J. Michael | journal=Presidential Studies Quarterly |date=Winter 1989 | volume=19 | issue=1 | pages=79–94}}</ref>
It was clear to organizers of the American effort that previous disease control efforts had been largely ineffective, as the causes of the two main diseases were unknown, but in 1897 it was proved by Britain's [[Ronald Ross]] in India that malaria was spread by mosquitoes.
== The Sanitation effort == The Canal Commission appointed Colonel [[William C. Gorgas|William Crawford Gorgas]] in March 1904 as head of hospitals and sanitation. Under his leadership, many new departments of sanitation were founded, covering different aspects of the sanitation problem. Commissions were also formed to look after the basic welfare of laborers.
The sanitation work included clearing land and establishing quarantine facilities. The most ambitious part of the sanitation program, though, was undoubtedly the effort to eradicate the mosquitoes ''[[Aedes aegypti]]'' and ''[[Anopheles]]'', the carriers of [[yellow fever]] and [[malaria]], respectively, from the canal zone. There was initially considerable resistance to this program, as the "mosquito theory" was still considered controversial and unproven. However, with the support of chief engineer [[John Frank Stevens]], who took over the post on July 26, 1905, Gorgas was finally able to put his ideas into action.
Gorgas divided [[Panama]] into 11 districts, and [[Colón, Panama]], into four. In each district, inspectors searched houses and buildings for mosquito larvae. If larvae were found, carpenters were dispatched to the building, and work was done to eliminate objects or places where [[Water stagnation|stagnant water]] could collect.
Mosquitoes lay their eggs on the surface of standing water, and when the [[larva]]e hatch, they live just below the surface, breathing through a siphon in their tails. Therefore, by eliminating standing water where possible and by spreading oil on the surface of any remaining pools, the larvae could be destroyed.
Gorgas also had domestic [[water supply network|water systems]] installed in urban areas around the Canal Zone. These systems eliminated the need for [[rainwater collection]], which had been collected in barrels and was a place for mosquitoes to breed. The United States government also provided $20 million to give workers free medical care and burial services. Gorgas's sanitation department also provided about one ton of [[History of malaria#Quinine|prophylactic quinine]] each year to people in the Canal Zone to combat malaria.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://ocp.hul.harvard.edu/contagion/panamacanal.html | title=Tropical Diseases and the Construction of the Panama Canal, 1904–1914 | publisher=Harvard University Library | accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref>
Gorgas organized a major program to drain and fill [[swamp]]s and [[wetland]]s around the Canal Zone. Many miles of ditches were dug, and grass and brush were cut back over wide areas. Oiling was used in a variety of means: workers with spray tanks were sent to spray oil on standing pools, and smaller streams were tackled by placing a dripping oil can over the waterway, which created a film of oil over each still patch of water in the stream. About 700,000 gallons of oil and 124,000 gallons of larvicide were used on the project. <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:YellowFeverMalariaGraph.jpg|frame|thumbnail|50px|As a result of Gorgas's actions, cases of malaria and yellow fever in the canal zone dropped dramatically in a short period of time.]] -->Gorgas also took another step in his efforts to eradicate mosquitoes in Panama: [[fumigation]]. He fumigated the residences of Panamanians who had been confirmed to have contracted yellow fever. "''Pans of [[sulfur]] or [[pyrethrum]] were then placed in the rooms, the right quantity of powder was weighed out (two pounds per thousand cubic feet), and the pans were sprinkled with wood-alcohol and set alight''" (Cameron 132). When the effectiveness of this procedure was realized, fumigation was extended to all of Panama. Within a year of Stevens's appointment, every building in Panama had been fumigated, using up the entire US supply of sulfur and pyrethrum. In 1906, only one case of yellow fever was reported, and until the end of the Panama Canal's construction, there were zero.
Gorgas's final means of attack on disease was to quarantine individuals infected with yellow fever or malaria from the rest of the workforce. Those who were diagnosed with either disease were put into "Portable Fever Cages", easily transportable screened structures used to prevent mosquitoes from biting an infected person and carrying the disease to others. Gorgas also had the thousands of canal workers sleep in screened verandas, as the mosquitoes that spread malaria are nocturnal and would infect the most people at night.
== Outcome == The first two and a half years of the American canal effort were substantially dedicated to preparation, much of it making the area fit for large-scale human habitation. A significant part of this was the sanitation program put in place by Gorgas. Nearly $20 million was spent on health and sanitation during the ten years.
In the end, these efforts were a success: by 1906, yellow fever was virtually wiped out in the Canal Zone, and the number of deaths caused by the other top disease, malaria, was also reduced significantly. The hospitals maintained were by far the best to be found anywhere in the tropics; some 32,000 patients were treated per year.
While disease reduction dramatically improved the health of white workers, black workers—the majority of the canal workforce—continued to die in large numbers, at ten times the rate of white workers in 1906.<ref>McCullough, pp. 501-502</ref> While medical care was provided to all, housing was not provided to black workers, many of whom had to live in tents and tenements outside the mosquito-controlled zone. In the end, 350 white workers had died compared to 4,500 black workers.<ref>McCullough, p. 610</ref> While the loss was tragic, it was far less than during the French era.
Today, the Panama canal area is regarded as free of yellow fever and malaria.
== References == {{Reflist}}
*{{note|ncid}}[http://www2.ncid.cdc.gov/travel/yb/utils/ybGet.asp?section=YBAll&cssNav=browseoyb ''Travelers' Health: Yellow Book'']—Centers for Disease Control * [http://www.czbrats.com/Menus/bennett.htm ''History of the Panama Canal''], Ira E. Bennett * ''Building the Panama Canal'', Arthur T. Schlesinger, ''Chronicles From National Geographic''. Chelsea House Publishers, Philadelphia, 1999. *Cameron, Ian (1972). ''The Impossible Dream: The Building of the Panama Canal''. New York: William Morrow & Company, Inc. * Mellander, Gustavo A.; Nelly Maldonado Mellander (1999). Charles Edward Magoon: The Panama Years. Río Piedras, Puerto Rico: Editorial Plaza Mayor. {{ISBN|1-56328-155-4}}. OCLC 42970390. * Mellander, Gustavo A. (1971). The United States in Panamanian Politics: The Intriguing Formative Years. Danville, Ill.: Interstate Publishers. OCLC 138568. {{Panama Canal}}
== External links == * http://ufdc.ufl.edu/AA00011604/00001/ Health and the Panama Canal * [http://www.sil.si.edu/Exhibitions/Make-the-Dirt-Fly/bugwar.html/ Smithsonian Institution "Waging War on Mosquitoes"]

{{COI|date=April 2018}} {{Other people|Ian Kennedy}} {{Infobox person | name = Sir Ian Kennedy [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] | image = Ian Kennedy hosting After Dark in 1987.JPG | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = Kennedy hosting the television discussion programme ''[[After Dark (TV series)|After Dark]]'' in 1987 | birth_name = Ian McColl Kennedy | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|09|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tipton]], Staffordshire<ref>{{cite journal | last=Hill | first=Stan | title=Eminent Black Country Folk - Ian McColl Kennedy | volume=21 | issue=4 | journal=The Blackcountryman | publisher=The Black Country Society | url=http://www.blackcountrysociety.co.uk/blackcountryman | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Academic [[Lawyer]] | education = [[King Edward VI College, Stourbridge]], Worcestershire<ref>{{cite book | title=Who's Who 2010 | edition=162 | isbn=978-1408114148 | date=7 December 2009 | publisher=[[A & C Black]]}}</ref> | alma_mater = | employer = [[University College London]] | occupation = [[Emeritus Professor]] of Health Law, Ethics and Policy | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | spouse = 1. Ilsa Echegaray (married 1967) (divorced c.1970) (died 2007)<ref name='UPR'>{{cite web|title=Healthy Organization Workgroup|url=http://pso.uprrp.edu/new_page_5.htm|work=Healthy Organization Workgroup|publisher=University of Puerto Rico|accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref> 2. Mary 3. Andrea Gage (married 1980)<ref name="DM09">{{cite web|title=MPs' expenses watchdog 'in wrong frame of mind' as third marriage fails after 29 years | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1226070/MPs-expenses-watchdog-wrong-frame-mind-marriage-fails.html | last=Walters | first=Simon | date=8 November 2009 | publisher = [[Daily Mail]] | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> | partner = | children = | parents = Robert Charles Kennedy and Dorothy Elizabeth Cowley<ref>{{cite web | title=ScotlandsPeople | publisher=[[National Records of Scotland]] | url =http://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Sir Ian McColl Kennedy''', [[Queen's Counsel|QC]]<ref>{{cite web | title=MPs' expenses: Profile of Sir Paul Kennedy, new judge of allowance claims | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mps-expenses/6711621/MPs-expenses-Profile-of-Sir-Paul-Kennedy-new-judge-of-allowance-claims.html | last=Swaine | first=Jon | publisher = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date=2 December 2009 | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> (born 14 September 1941) is a British academic [[lawyer]] who has specialised in the law and ethics of [[health care|health]]. He was appointed to chair the [[Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web | title=Profile: Sir Ian Kennedy | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/nov/04/sir-ian-kennedy-profile | last=Tran | first=Mark | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | date=4 November 2009 | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
==Education and academic career== 1952–1959: He attended [[King Edward VI College, Stourbridge]], Worcestershire where he spent four years in the sixth form.
1960–1963: He attended [[University College, London]], graduated 1st class Hons. LLB.
1963–1965: [[Fulbright Fellow]] at [[University of California, Berkeley]] (LLM).
1965–1971: Sub-Dean, Tutor and Lecturer in Law at University College, London (LLD).
1966–1967: [[Ford Foundation]] fellow of Yale University and Mexico University.
In the summer of 1969 Kennedy visited [[Cuba]] to study the administration of justice, supported by a Hayter Fellowship awarded by the [[Institute of Latin American Studies]], University of London (by Prof. R.A. Humphreys). In December/January 1970 – 1971 he returned to Cuba to gain information for his paper titled “Cuba's Ley Contra La Vagancia - The Law on Loafing”.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Kennedy | first=Ian McColl | title=Cuba's Ley Contra La Vagancia - The Law on Loafing | page=1177 | volume=20 | year=1973 | journal=UCLA Law Review | publisher=[[UCLA School of Law]] | url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/uclalr20&div=46 | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
Kennedy was Dean of the Law School at [[King's College London]], from 1986 to 1996. Kennedy is [[Emeritus Professor]] of Health Law, Ethics and Policy at [[University College London]]. He is an honorary [[Bencher]] of the [[Inner Temple]].
Kennedy was the [[BBC]]'s [[Reith Lectures|Reith lecturer]] (on the subject of "Unmasking Medicine") in 1980<ref>{{cite web | title=The Reith Lectures: Unmasking Medicine, Ian Kennedy, 1980 | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00gq1z0/episodes/guide | publisher = [[BBC]] | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> and hosted many editions of ''[[After Dark (TV series)|After Dark]]'' on [[Channel 4]].<ref>{{cite web | title=After Dark | url=http://www.openmedia.co.uk/afterdark.htm | publisher=[[Open Media]] | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
==Committees and inquiries==
Kennedy has been a member of numerous committees and inquiries.<ref name="UKRIO"/>
For nine years, he was a member of the [[General Medical Council]]. In 1978, he founded the Centre of Medical Laws and Ethics, of which he later became president. He also served as member of the [[Medicines Commission]], and the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] advisory group on [[AIDS]]. He is a member of the board of the [[UK Research Integrity Office]].<ref name="UKRIO">{{cite web | url=http://www.ukrio.org/about-us/board-members/ | title=Advisory Board Members | publisher=[[UK Research Integrity Office]] | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
In 1997, he took part in a [[UK Government]] inquiry that gave cautious approval to [[xenotransplantation]] (the use of animal-to-human transplants), and in 1998, was a member of the committee that recommended [[pet passport]]s.
Kennedy was a member of the [[Nuffield Council on Bioethics]] 1991-2002 and Chair during 1998-2002.
Kennedy is a trustee of homeless health charity Pathway.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pathway - Our People|url=http://www.pathway.org.uk/about-us/our-people/|website=Pathway - Healthcare for Homeless People|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
He chaired the public inquiry into children's heart surgery at the [[Bristol Royal Infirmary]] (1998–2001),<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bristol-inquiry.org.uk/about/whos_who/index.htm | title=Who's who | publisher=The Bristol Royal Infirmary Inquiry | archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20090811143745/http://www.bristol-inquiry.org.uk/about/whos_who/index.htm | archivedate=11 August 2009 | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> which concluded that paediatric cardiac surgery services at Bristol were "simply not up to the task", because of shortages of key surgeons and nurses, and a lack of leadership, accountability, and teamwork. This resulted in his becoming chair of the [[Healthcare Commission]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.healthcarecommission.org.uk/aboutus/whoarewe/thecommissioners.cfm | title=About us - The Commissioners | archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080930073207/http://www.healthcarecommission.org.uk/aboutus/whoarewe/thecommissioners.cfm | publisher=[[Healthcare Commission]] | archivedate=30 September 2008 | accessdate = 9 January 2013}}</ref> from its creation (in shadow form) in 2003, until it was merged with other regulatory bodies to form the [[Care Quality Commission]] in 2009. In October 2009, Kennedy became chair of the [[King's Fund]]’s inquiry into the quality of general practice in England, replacing [[Niall Dickson]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Sir Ian Kennedy joins The King's Fund's inquiry into the quality of general practice | url=http://www.kingsfund.org.uk/press/press-releases/sir-ian-kennedy-joins-kings-funds-inquiry-quality-general-practice | publisher=[[King's Fund]] | date=21 October 2009 | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> He led an enquiry into the work of breast surgeon [[Ian Paterson]] in Birmingham in 2013.
==Involvement in medicine and alternative medicine== In 2010, he was elected inaugural Vice-President of the ''[[College of Medicine (UK)|College of Medicine]],''<ref>{{ cite web | title=Professor Sir Ian Kennedy | url=http://www.collegeofmedicine.org.uk/professor-sir-ian-kennedy | publisher=[[The College of Medicine]] | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> an organisation set up to bring together patients and clincians on an equal footing.<ref>{{cite web | title=About the College of Medicine | publisher=[[The College of Medicine]] | url=http://www.collegeofmedicine.org.uk/about-college-medicine | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> Several commentators, writing in [[The Guardian]]<ref name=GuardianCollege>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/aug/02/prince-charles-college-medicine-holistic-complementary |title=College of Medicine born from ashes of Prince Charles's holistic health charity |author=Ian Sample |publisher=The Guardian |date=August 2, 2010 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2012/jan/10/college-medicine-lobby-group-unproven |title=College of Medicine is a lobby group promoting unproven treatments |author=Edzard Ernst |publisher=The [[The Guardian|Guardian]] |date=10 January 2012}}</ref> and [[The British Medical Journal]]<ref name=BMJ_Cassidy>{{cite journal | journal=British Medical Journal | volume=343 | doi=10.1136/bmj.d3712 | date=15 June 2011 | title=Lobby Watch: The College of Medicine | author=Jane Cassidy | url=http://www.bmj.com/content/342/bmj.d3712.full | pmid=21677014}}</ref><ref name=BMJ_Colquhoun>{{cite journal | journal=British Medical Journal | volume=343 | doi=10.1136/bmj.d4368 | date=12 July 2011 | title=The College of Medicine is Prince’s Foundation reincarnated | author=David Colquhoun | url=http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d4368.full | pmid=21750061}}</ref><ref name=BMJ_May>{{cite journal | journal=British Medical Journal | volume=343 | doi=10.1136/bmj.d4372 | date=12 July 2011 | title=College of Medicine: What is integrative health? | author=James May | url=http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d4372.full | pmid=21750063}}</ref><ref name=BMJ_Ernst>{{cite journal | journal=British Medical Journal | volume=343 | doi=10.1136/bmj.d4370 | date=12 July 2011 | title=College of Medicine or College of Quackery? | author=Edzard Ernst | url=http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d4370.full | pmid=21750062}}</ref> claim that this organisation is simply a re-branding of Prince Charles' [[alternative medicine]] lobbying group the ''[[The Prince's Foundation for Integrated Health|Foundation for Integrated Health]].'' This has been denied by the College of Medicine<ref>{{cite journal | title=College of Medicine replies to its critics | publisher=[[BMJ]] | year=2011 | volume=343 | pages=4364 | doi=10.1136/bmj.d4364 | url=http://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d4364 | accessdate=9 January 2013 | pmid=21750060}}</ref> whose President is [[Graeme Catto]], for seven years the President of the [[General Medical Council]].
===Awards=== Kennedy was [[Knight bachelor|knighted]] in 2002 for services to medical law and [[bioethics]]. He is an [[Honorary Fellow]] of:<ref name="UKRIO"/>
*[[British Academy]] (2002) *[[Royal College of General Practitioners]] (2002) *[[Royal College of Physicians]] (2003) *[[Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health]] (2004) *[[Royal College of Anaesthetists]] (2004) *[[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] (2005) *[[Chartered Institute of Internal Auditors]] (2009)
He was also awarded an Honorary [[Doctor of Science#The Commonwealth of Nations and Ireland|DSc]] degree by the [[University of Glasgow]] in 2003.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Biography of Professor Sir Ian Kennedy | url=http://www.parliamentaryyearbook2009.co.uk/CP/the-nhs-today-professor-sir-ian-kennedy-chairman-of-the-healthcare-commission.html | journal=Blakes Parliamentary Yearbook | year=2009 | publisher=Blake Media | accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
==Publications== *{{cite book | title=The Unmasking of Medicine | first=Ian | last=Kennedy | publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]] | pages=240 | date=11 June 1981 | ISBN=978-0046100162}} *{{cite book | title=Treat Me Right: Essays in Medical Law and Ethics | last=Kennedy | first=Ian | publisher=[[Clarendon Paperbacks]] | pages=446 | date=19 September 1991 | ISBN=978-0198255581}} *{{cite book| title = Medical Law: Text and Materials | last1=Kennedy | first1=Ian | last2=Grubb | first2=Andrew | publisher=[[Butterworths Law]] | pages=1200 | date=March 1994 | ISBN=978-0406006233}} *{{cite book | title=Law, Medicine and Ethics: Essays in Honour of Lord Jakobovits | first1=Harry | last1=Woolf | first2=Ian | last2=Kennedy | first3=Gloria | last3=Freilich | first4=Liam | last4=Donaldson | first5=John | last5=Carrier | publisher=[[Cancerkin]] | pages=224 | date=February 2007| ISBN=978-0955479908}} *{{cite book | title=Principles of Medical Law | first1=Ian | last1=Kennedy | editor1-first=Andrew | editor1-last=Grubb | editor2-first=Judith | editor2-last=Laing | editor3-first=Jean | editor3-last=McHale | publisher=[[Oxford University Press|OUP Oxford]] | pages=1320 | date=9 December 2010 | ISBN=978-0199544400}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links ==

{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kennedy, Ian}}
[[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English barristers]] [[Category:English people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Alumni of University College London]] [[Category:Academics of University College London]] [[Category:Academics of King's College London]] [[Category:Fellows of King's College London]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of General Practitioners]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Physicians]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Anaesthetists]] [[Category:Bioethics]] [[Category:Health law in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:Lawyers awarded knighthoods]] [[Category:People educated at King Edward VI College, Stourbridge]] [[Category:Ford Foundation fellowships]]

An '''internalizing disorder''' ([[American and British English spelling differences#-ise.2C -ize .28-isation.2C -ization.29|or]] '''internalising disorder''') is one type of [[emotional and behavioral disorder]], along with [[Externalizing Disorders|externalizing disorders]], and low incidence disorders.<ref name=Smith>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=D.D.|title=Emotional or Behavioral Disorders Defined|url=http://www.education.com/reference/article/emotional-behavioral-disorders-defined/|work=education.com|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref> One who has an internalizing disorder will keep their problems to themselves, or [[Internalization#Internalization as symptom|internalize]] the problems.
== Symptoms == Behaviors that are apparent in those with internalizing disorders include [[Depression (mood)|depression]], withdrawal, [[anxiety]], and loneliness.<ref name=Smith/> There are also behavioral characteristics involved with internalizing disorders. Some behavioral abnormalities include poor [[self-esteem]], [[suicide|suicidal behaviors]], decreased academic progress, and social withdrawal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Internalizing Symptoms and Affect of Children with Emotional and Behavioral Disorders|url=http://www.studymode.com/essays/Internalizing-Symptoms-And-Affect-Of-Children-866577.html|work=studymode.com|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref> Internalizing one's problems, like sadness, can cause the problems to grow into larger burdens such as social withdrawal, suicidal behaviors or thoughts, and other unexplained physical symptoms.<ref>{{cite web|last=DiMaria|first=Lauren|title=Internalizing Behaviors and Depression|url=http://depression.about.com/od/depressionsymptoms/a/internalizing-behaviors.htm|work=about.com|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref>
==DSM-5== The internalizing disorders, with high levels of negative affectivity, include [[depression (mood)|depressive disorders]], [[anxiety|anxiety disorders]], obsessive-compulsive and related disorders, trauma and stressor-related disorders, and dissociative disorders.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Regier|first1=Darrel A.|last2=Kuhl|first2=Emily A.|last3=Kupfer|first3=David J.|title=The DSM-5: Classification and criteria changes|journal=World Psychiatry|date=June 2013|volume=12|issue=2|pages=92–98|doi=10.1002/wps.20050|pmc=3683251|pmid=23737408}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Turygin|first1=Nicole C.|last2=Matson|first2=Johnny L.|last3=Adams|first3=Hilary|last4=Belva|first4=Brian|title=The effect of DSM-5 criteria on externalizing, internalizing, behavioral and adaptive symptoms in children diagnosed with autism|journal=Developmental Neurorehabilitation|date=August 2013|volume=16|issue=4|pages=277–282|doi=10.3109/17518423.2013.769281|pmid=23617257}}</ref> Others like [[bulimia]], and [[Anorexia nervosa|anorexia]] also come under this category.<ref name=Smith/>
== Treatment == Some treatments for internalizing disorders include [[antidepressants]], [[electroconvulsive therapy]], and [[psychotherapy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Depression|url=http://www.helpguide.org/mental/depression_signs_types_diagnosis_treatment.htm|work=helpguide.org|accessdate=17 March 2014}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Anxiety]] * [[Depression (mood)|Depression]] * [[Emotional and behavioral disorders]] * [[Externalizing disorders]]
